name: State_3

timeline_beats.label: Rise as regional port-league and shipbuilding center
Maritime expansion; colonial outposts & island bases established
Great Naval War impacts fleet and trade routes
Open-Seas Treaty and entry into Sea Trade Union
Succession crisis of neighbor leads to coastal acquisition

factions.label: Merchants' Grand Gild
factions.influence_hint: dominant in urban councils; controls long-distance trade

factions.label: Harbour Nobility
factions.influence_hint: landed elites; finance fortifications and magistracies

factions.label: Shipwrights' Conclave
factions.influence_hint: technical guild; controls shipbuilding and naval contracts

factions.label: Tide-Templars
factions.influence_hint: religious order; maritime auguries and port rites

factions.label: Smugglers' Syndicate
factions.influence_hint: informal; undermines tariffs, strong in fringe isles

traits: oral sea-chant epics and seasonal festivals
pragmatic mercantile ethics with patronage networks

constraints: No instant resurrection or true life-replacement magics
Long-range mind influence is rare and institutionally banned
Navigational auguries exist but cannot replace charts and seamanship
Ritual magic consumes scarce imported reagents or specialized labour
Combustion-derived industry limited (no high-pressure steam megatechs)
notes: Heavy dependence on imported ritual reagents; trade disruptions cause sharp ritual/service shortages
Port defenses and shipwright capacity are strategic vulnerabilities and factional focal points
Recent coastal acquisition (BC3) leaves frontier governance contested with State_2 remnants
Membership in Maritime Trading League and Sea Trade Union shapes tariff regimes and convoy obligations
